3. Ἐπιτηδεύματα. They are defined by Menander1 as ἄνευ ἀγώνων ἤθη, and it does not seem accidental that by far the larger number of ethical or personal traits of Agricola is · accumulated in the very next chapters in accordance with the rhetorical rules, and that there is, in fact, scarcely one of these characteristica which is not paralleled in Hermoge nes, Theon, Menander, and others.²
